reactions.name: Photosynthesis (overall)
reactions.conditions: chlorophyll; light energy (sunlight); thylakoid membranes
reactions.description: Converts light energy to chemical energy. Produces all atmospheric O2. Calvin cycle fixes CO2.

reactions.name: Photosynthesis light reaction (water splitting)
reactions.conditions: photosystem II; Mn4CaO5 cluster (OEC); 680 nm light
reactions.description: Water oxidation at PSII oxygen-evolving complex. Source of all biological O2.

reactions.name: Cellular respiration (overall)
reactions.conditions: glycolysis + Krebs cycle + oxidative phosphorylation; ~30-32 ATP per glucose
reactions.description: Complete oxidation of glucose. Exact reverse of photosynthesis. Powers all aerobic life.

reactions.name: Glycolysis (net reaction)
reactions.equation: C6H12O6(s) + 2 NAD+(aq) + 2 ADP(aq) + 2 Pi(aq) -> 2 CH3COCOO-(aq) + 2 NADH(aq) + 2 ATP(aq) + 2 H2O(l)
reactions.conditions: cytoplasm; 10 enzyme-catalyzed steps
reactions.description: Glucose to 2 pyruvate. Net 2 ATP + 2 NADH. Universal pathway in all domains of life.

reactions.name: Ethanol fermentation
reactions.conditions: zymase (yeast enzymes); anaerobic conditions; Saccharomyces cerevisiae
reactions.description: Anaerobic glucose metabolism by yeast. Produces beer, wine, bread (CO2 leavening).

reactions.name: Lactic acid fermentation
reactions.conditions: lactate dehydrogenase; anaerobic; muscle cells during intense exercise
reactions.description: Anaerobic pathway in muscle. Also used by Lactobacillus in yogurt/sauerkraut production.

reactions.name: Krebs cycle (overall per acetyl-CoA)
reactions.equation: Acetyl-CoA + 3 NAD+ + FAD + GDP + Pi + 2 H2O -> CoA-SH + 2 CO2 + 3 NADH + FADH2 + GTP
reactions.conditions: mitochondrial matrix; 8 enzyme-catalyzed steps; regulated by [ATP]/[ADP]
reactions.description: Central metabolic hub. Oxidizes acetyl groups to CO2, generating electron carriers for ETC.

reactions.name: Beta-oxidation of fatty acids (per cycle)
reactions.equation: Acyl-CoA(Cn) + FAD + NAD+ + CoA-SH + H2O -> Acyl-CoA(Cn-2) + FADH2 + NADH + Acetyl-CoA
reactions.conditions: mitochondrial matrix; 4 enzymes per cycle; each cycle removes 2 carbons
reactions.description: Fatty acid catabolism. Each cycle yields 1 FADH2, 1 NADH, 1 acetyl-CoA (~14 ATP per cycle).

reactions.name: Hydroxyapatite formation (bone mineralization)
reactions.conditions: osteoblast-mediated; alkaline phosphatase; collagen matrix template
reactions.description: Hydroxyapatite is the mineral component of bone and teeth. ~70% of bone mass.

reactions.name: Hemoglobin oxygen binding
reactions.conditions: cooperative binding (sigmoidal curve); Fe2+ in heme porphyrin; P50 = 26 mmHg
reactions.description: Cooperative O2 binding to hemoglobin's four heme groups. Fe2+ does NOT oxidize to Fe3+.

reactions.name: Cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV)
reactions.equation: 4 cytochrome c (Fe2+) + O2 + 8 H+(matrix) -> 4 cytochrome c (Fe3+) + 2 H2O + 4 H+(IMS)
reactions.conditions: inner mitochondrial membrane; contains CuA, CuB, heme a, heme a3
reactions.description: Terminal oxidase of electron transport chain. Reduces O2 to H2O. Pumps 4 H+ per O2.

reactions.name: Chlorophyll light absorption
reactions.conditions: absorbs red (680 nm) and blue (430 nm); Mg2+ coordinated by porphyrin ring
reactions.description: Chlorophyll absorbs light via Mg-porphyrin chromophore. Excited electron enters photosystem.

reactions.name: Biological nitrogen fixation
reactions.equation: N2(g) + 8 H+(aq) + 8 e- + 16 ATP(aq) -> 2 NH3(aq) + H2(g) + 16 ADP(aq) + 16 Pi(aq)
reactions.conditions: nitrogenase (Fe-Mo cofactor); obligate anaerobic conditions for enzyme; Rhizobium in legume root nodules
reactions.description: Nitrogenase reduces N2 to NH3 at ambient conditions. Requires 16 ATP per N2. FeMo cofactor active site.

reactions.name: Urease catalysis
reactions.conditions: urease (Ni2+ active site); rate enhancement: 10^14 over uncatalyzed
reactions.description: Urease was the first enzyme crystallized (Sumner, 1926). Contains dinuclear Ni center.

reactions.name: ATP hydrolysis
reactions.conditions: Mg2+ cofactor; standard biochemical conditions (pH 7, 1mM)
reactions.description: Universal energy currency of life. Drives endergonic reactions by coupling. ~100 kg ATP recycled/day in humans.

reactions.name: ATP synthesis (oxidative phosphorylation)
reactions.conditions: ATP synthase (Complex V); proton motive force across inner mitochondrial membrane
reactions.description: Chemiosmotic synthesis of ATP. F1Fo-ATP synthase rotary motor. ~26-28 ATP from one glucose.

reactions.name: Disulfide bond formation (protein folding)
reactions.conditions: endoplasmic reticulum; protein disulfide isomerase (PDI)
reactions.description: Cysteine disulfide bridges stabilize protein tertiary structure. Oxidizing environment of ER.

reactions.name: Carbonic anhydrase
reactions.conditions: carbonic anhydrase (Zn2+ active site); kcat ~10^6 s-1; one of fastest enzymes
reactions.description: Zinc metalloenzyme. Catalyzes CO2 hydration ~10^6 times faster than uncatalyzed. Critical for CO2 transport and pH regulation.

reactions.name: Ocean acidification
reactions.conditions: oceans absorb ~30% of anthropogenic CO2; pH dropped from 8.2 to 8.1 since pre-industrial
reactions.description: CO2 dissolution lowers ocean pH. Threatens coral reefs and shellfish (CaCO3 dissolution).

reactions.name: Methanogenesis
reactions.conditions: methanogenic archaea; strictly anaerobic; wetlands, ruminant guts, landfills
reactions.description: Archaeal methanogenesis. Major biogenic CH4 source. Contributes to greenhouse effect.

reactions.name: Methane oxidation (atmospheric sink)
reactions.conditions: hydroxyl radical (OH*) initiated; tropospheric lifetime ~12 years
reactions.description: Atmospheric methane removal by OH radical. Primary sink for CH4 greenhouse gas.

reactions.name: Chemical weathering of limestone
reactions.conditions: rain dissolves atmospheric CO2 forming weak carbonic acid
reactions.description: Creates caves, karst topography. Major CO2 sink on geological timescale. Causes hard water.

reactions.name: Iron rusting
reactions.conditions: electrochemical process; accelerated by salt, acid, scratches in protective coating
reactions.description: Iron corrosion is an electrochemical process. Costs ~3.4% of global GDP annually.

reactions.name: Rust dehydration
reactions.conditions: ambient conditions; Fe(OH)3 dehydrates to reddish-brown rust
reactions.description: Hydrated iron(III) oxide (rust). Flaky, non-protective. Unlike Al2O3, does not passivate.

reactions.name: Mercury methylation (bioaccumulation)
reactions.conditions: anaerobic sulfate-reducing bacteria; wetlands and sediments
reactions.description: Methylmercury bioaccumulates in food chains. Minamata disease. Extremely neurotoxic.

reactions.name: Acid rain from NO2
reactions.conditions: atmospheric; NOx from combustion engines and power plants
reactions.description: NOx forms nitric acid in atmosphere. Contributes to acid rain (pH < 5.6).

reactions.name: Denitrification
reactions.conditions: anaerobic bacteria (Pseudomonas); wetlands; wastewater treatment
reactions.description: Microbial conversion of nitrate back to N2. Closes the nitrogen cycle. Important in wastewater treatment.

reactions.name: Nitrification (ammonia to nitrate)
reactions.conditions: two-step: Nitrosomonas (NH3->NO2-) then Nitrobacter (NO2-->NO3-); aerobic soil
reactions.description: Two-step microbial oxidation. Converts ammonium fertilizer to plant-available nitrate.

reactions.name: Lead pipe corrosion (historical)
reactions.conditions: soft water dissolves Pb(OH)2; hard water forms protective PbCO3 scale
reactions.description: Lead leaching from pipes. Flint water crisis (2014). Roman plumbing (plumbum = lead).

reactions.name: Acid rain from SO2
reactions.conditions: atmospheric oxidation; SO2 from coal/ore smelting
reactions.description: Sulfuric acid formation in atmosphere. Major cause of acid rain. Addressed by Clean Air Act.

reactions.name: Sulfate reduction (deep ocean)
reactions.conditions: sulfate-reducing bacteria (Desulfovibrio); anaerobic marine sediments
reactions.description: Microbial sulfate reduction. Produces H2S (rotten egg smell). Forms black FeS in sediments.

reactions.name: Silicate weathering (CO2 sink)
reactions.equation: CaSiO3(s) + 2 CO2(g) + 3 H2O(l) -> Ca2+(aq) + 2 HCO3-(aq) + H4SiO4(aq)
reactions.conditions: geological timescale; thermostat of Earth's climate
reactions.description: Silicate weathering is the primary geological CO2 sink. Urey reaction controls climate over millions of years.

reactions.name: Bayer process (alumina extraction)
reactions.conditions: 523 K; 30 atm; digestion of bauxite in hot caustic soda
reactions.description: Bayer process extracts alumina from bauxite ore. Precursor to Hall-Heroult.

reactions.name: Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (general)
reactions.equation: n CO(g) + (2n+1) H2(g) -> CnH(2n+2)(l) + n H2O(g)
reactions.conditions: 523 K; 25 atm; iron or cobalt
reactions.description: Converts syngas to liquid hydrocarbons. Used for gas-to-liquids (GTL) and coal-to-liquids.

reactions.name: Methanol synthesis
reactions.conditions: 523 K; 80 atm; Cu/ZnO/Al2O3
reactions.description: Industrial methanol synthesis from syngas. ~100 million tonnes/year globally.

reactions.name: Ethylene production (steam cracking)
reactions.conditions: 1123 K; steam cracking; residence time <1 second
reactions.description: Thermal dehydrogenation of ethane to ethylene. Largest-volume petrochemical.

reactions.name: Polyethylene polymerization
reactions.conditions: Ziegler-Natta (TiCl4/AlEt3) or metallocene; various pressures by process type
reactions.description: Polymerization of ethylene to polyethylene. Most-produced plastic globally.

reactions.name: Catalytic cracking (general)
reactions.conditions: 773 K; zeolite (USY or ZSM-5); FCC unit; 2-5 second contact time
reactions.description: Fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) of heavy petroleum fractions into gasoline.

reactions.name: Methane combustion
reactions.conditions: ignition source required
reactions.description: Natural gas combustion. Cleanest-burning fossil fuel.

reactions.name: Chloralkali electrolysis
reactions.conditions: membrane cell electrolysis at ~3.5 V
reactions.description: Produces chlorine, sodium hydroxide, and hydrogen simultaneously.

reactions.name: PVC production (vinyl chloride)
reactions.conditions: FeCl3
reactions.description: Direct chlorination of ethylene to 1,2-dichloroethane (EDC). Precursor to PVC.

reactions.name: Hydrogen combustion
reactions.conditions: ignition or spark required
reactions.description: Highly exothermic combustion producing water.

reactions.name: Steam methane reforming
reactions.conditions: 1100 K; 20 atm; nickel on alumina
reactions.description: Primary industrial hydrogen production method. Produces syngas.

reactions.name: Water-gas shift reaction
reactions.conditions: 623 K; iron oxide (HTS) or Cu-ZnO-Al2O3 (LTS)
reactions.description: Converts CO and steam to CO2 and H2. Used after steam reforming.

reactions.name: Water electrolysis
reactions.conditions: electrolysis; PEM or alkaline electrolyzer
reactions.description: Green hydrogen production via electrolysis. Growing rapidly for decarbonization.

reactions.name: Haber process (ammonia synthesis)
reactions.conditions: 723 K; 200 atm; iron with K2O/Al2O3 promoters
reactions.description: Primary industrial route to ammonia. ~150 million tonnes/year globally.

reactions.name: Ostwald process step 1 (ammonia oxidation)
reactions.conditions: 1100 K; platinum-rhodium gauze (90% Pt / 10% Rh)
reactions.description: First step of Ostwald process for nitric acid. ~95% yield with Pt-Rh catalyst.

reactions.name: Ostwald process step 3 (nitric acid formation)
reactions.description: Final step producing nitric acid. The NO byproduct is recycled to step 2.

reactions.name: Urea synthesis
reactions.conditions: 458 K; 175 atm; two-step via ammonium carbamate
reactions.description: Bosch-Meiser process. World's most-produced chemical by mass (~180 Mt/y). Fertilizer.

reactions.name: Solvay process (key precipitation step)
reactions.equation: NaCl(aq) + NH3(aq) + CO2(g) + H2O(l) -> NaHCO3(s) + NH4Cl(aq)
reactions.conditions: 288 K; CO2 bubbled through ammoniacal brine
reactions.description: NaHCO3 precipitates due to low solubility. Filtered and calcined to Na2CO3.

reactions.name: Sodium hydroxide + CO2 (caustic scrubbing)
reactions.description: Caustic scrubbing of CO2 from flue gas or process streams.

reactions.name: Phosphoric acid production (wet process)
reactions.description: Wet-process phosphoric acid for fertilizer production. Gypsum (CaSO4) byproduct.

reactions.name: Contact process step 3 (oleum formation)
reactions.description: SO3 absorbed into concentrated H2SO4 to form oleum (fuming sulfuric acid).

reactions.name: Oleum dilution to sulfuric acid
reactions.description: Oleum diluted with water to produce concentrated sulfuric acid.

reactions.name: Claus process (main reaction)
reactions.conditions: 573 K; alumina or titanium dioxide
reactions.description: Recovers elemental sulfur from H2S in natural gas/refinery streams. >95% recovery.

reactions.name: Bromine water test for unsaturation
reactions.description: Decolorization of bromine water indicates C=C double bond. Classic qualitative test.

reactions.name: CO2 generation (marble + HCl)
reactions.description: Reaction of marble chips (CaCO3) with hydrochloric acid. Common CO2 source in lab.

reactions.name: Fischer esterification
reactions.conditions: concentrated H2SO4; reflux; equilibrium reaction
reactions.description: Acid-catalyzed esterification. Ethyl acetate has fruity smell. Common teaching reaction.

reactions.name: Saponification (ester hydrolysis)
reactions.conditions: heating; irreversible (OH- drives to completion)
reactions.description: Base hydrolysis of an ester. Called saponification when applied to fats (soap making).

reactions.name: Grignard reaction (general)
reactions.conditions: anhydrous diethyl ether; strictly dry glassware; N2 atmosphere
reactions.description: Grignard reagent adds to carbonyl. Produces secondary alcohol from aldehyde. Nobel Prize 1912.

reactions.name: Aldol condensation
reactions.conditions: NaOH (dilute); low temperature favors aldol; heat gives crotonaldehyde
reactions.description: Aldol addition forms beta-hydroxy aldehyde. Cornerstone of organic synthesis.

reactions.name: Cannizzaro reaction (benzaldehyde)
reactions.conditions: concentrated NaOH; aldehydes without alpha-H
reactions.description: Non-enolizable aldehyde disproportionation to acid + alcohol. Named for Stanislao Cannizzaro.

reactions.name: Tollens' test (silver mirror)
reactions.equation: RCHO(aq) + 2 [Ag(NH3)2]+(aq) + 2 OH-(aq) -> RCOO-(aq) + 2 Ag(s) + 4 NH3(aq) + H2O(l)
reactions.conditions: warm gently; silver deposits as mirror on clean glass
reactions.description: Silver mirror test distinguishes aldehydes from ketones. Ag+ reduced to metallic silver.

reactions.name: Fehling's test (reducing sugars)
reactions.equation: RCHO(aq) + 2 Cu2+(aq) + 5 OH-(aq) -> RCOO-(aq) + Cu2O(s) + 3 H2O(l)
reactions.conditions: heat to boiling; blue Cu2+ to brick-red Cu2O precipitate
reactions.description: Brick-red Cu2O precipitate indicates reducing sugar or aldehyde. Blue to red color change.

reactions.name: Chlorine generation (MnO2 + HCl)
reactions.conditions: use concentrated HCl; fume hood required
reactions.description: Laboratory chlorine preparation. Scheele's original 1774 method.

reactions.name: Dichromate titration of iron(II)
reactions.conditions: diphenylamine or ferroin indicator
reactions.description: Dichromate is a primary standard (unlike permanganate). Orange to green color change.

reactions.name: Copper(II) ammonia complex (deep blue)
reactions.conditions: add excess ammonia to Cu2+ solution
reactions.description: Tetraamminecopper(II) complex. Deep royal blue color. Confirms Cu2+ presence.

reactions.name: Strong acid-base neutralization (HCl + NaOH)
reactions.description: Fundamental acid-base neutralization. Enthalpy is -57.1 kJ/mol for all strong acid-strong base pairs.

reactions.name: Sulfuric acid + sodium hydroxide
reactions.description: Diprotic acid neutralization. Two moles of NaOH required per mole of H2SO4.

reactions.name: Acetic acid + NaOH (weak acid titration)
reactions.conditions: phenolphthalein indicator; endpoint pH ~8.7
reactions.description: Weak acid-strong base titration. Equivalence point is basic due to conjugate base hydrolysis.

reactions.name: Hydrogen generation (Zn + HCl)
reactions.description: Standard lab preparation of hydrogen gas. Collect by downward displacement of water.

reactions.name: Permanganate titration of iron(II)
reactions.equation: MnO4-(aq) + 5 Fe2+(aq) + 8 H+(aq) -> Mn2+(aq) + 5 Fe3+(aq) + 4 H2O(l)
reactions.conditions: self-indicating; purple MnO4- decolorizes until endpoint
reactions.description: Classic redox titration. MnO4- is its own indicator (purple to colorless).

reactions.name: Ammonia from ammonium salt + base
reactions.conditions: gentle heating
reactions.description: Lab preparation of ammonia. Detected by moist red litmus turning blue.

reactions.name: Ammonium dichromate volcano
reactions.conditions: ignite with match; spectacular volcanic eruption; toxic Cr(III) product
reactions.description: Chemical volcano demonstration. Self-sustaining decomposition once ignited.

reactions.name: Oxygen from hydrogen peroxide
reactions.conditions: MnO2 (catalase enzyme in biology)
reactions.description: Catalytic decomposition of hydrogen peroxide. Elephant toothpaste demo uses concentrated H2O2 + KI.

reactions.name: Sulfur dioxide generation
reactions.conditions: fume hood required; SO2 is toxic
reactions.description: Lab preparation of SO2 from sulfite salt and acid. Bleaches damp litmus.

reactions.name: Gold dissolution in aqua regia
reactions.equation: Au(s) + 3 HCl(aq) + HNO3(aq) -> HAuCl4(aq) + NO(g) + 2 H2O(l)
reactions.conditions: 3:1 HCl:HNO3 mixture; chloride complexation drives dissolution
reactions.description: Aqua regia dissolves gold. Neither acid alone works. Cl- complexation (AuCl4-) shifts equilibrium. de Hevesy saved Nobel medals this way in WWII.

reactions.name: Bismuth subsalicylate (Pepto-Bismol pink)
reactions.description: Bismuth is the heaviest non-radioactive element used in medicine. Pepto-Bismol's pink active ingredient.

reactions.name: Elephant toothpaste
reactions.conditions: KI or MnO2; 30% H2O2 + dish soap + KI; massive foam eruption
reactions.description: Rapid catalytic decomposition of concentrated H2O2. O2 trapped in soap creates massive foam column.

reactions.name: Caesium in water
reactions.conditions: explosive; shatters glass container; Coulomb explosion (2015 Nature Chemistry)
reactions.description: Most violent alkali metal + water. Explodes instantly. 2015 study showed Coulomb explosion mechanism.

reactions.name: Fluorine + water
reactions.conditions: fluorine oxidizes water (unique among halogens); extremely dangerous
reactions.description: Fluorine is the only element that oxidizes water at room temperature. Most reactive element.

reactions.name: Hydrogen fusion (proton-proton chain)
reactions.conditions: 15000000 K; stellar core; requires ~15 million K to overcome Coulomb barrier
reactions.description: Powers the Sun and main-sequence stars. Converts 4 protons to helium-4. E = mc^2: 0.7% mass converted to energy.

reactions.name: Deuterium-tritium fusion (ITER target)
reactions.conditions: 100000000 K; tokamak magnetic confinement; ITER target: Q >= 10
reactions.description: Easiest fusion reaction to achieve. 17.6 MeV per event. ITER aims for net energy gain.

reactions.name: Potassium in water
reactions.conditions: more violent than Na; lilac flame from K vapor; may explode
reactions.description: Even more violent than sodium. H2 always ignites with lilac flame. Can explode.

reactions.name: Lithium in water
reactions.conditions: gentle fizzing; lithium floats and slowly dissolves; crimson specks
reactions.description: Least violent alkali metal + water. Gentle fizzing. Li has highest ionization energy of group 1.

reactions.name: Briggs-Rauscher oscillating reaction
reactions.equation: IO3-(aq) + 2 H2O2(aq) + CH2(COOH)2(aq) + H+(aq) -> ICH(COOH)2(aq) + 2 O2(g) + 3 H2O(l)
reactions.conditions: MnSO4; oscillates amber -> blue -> colorless for ~10 cycles
reactions.description: Chemical oscillator. Color cycles amber -> blue -> colorless repeatedly. Non-equilibrium thermodynamics.

reactions.name: Ammonium nitrate decomposition (explosive)
reactions.conditions: detonation >270C; Beirut 2020 (2750 tonnes); Texas City 1947; Oppau 1921
reactions.description: Ammonium nitrate detonation. Responsible for numerous industrial disasters. Also a common fertilizer.

reactions.name: Sodium in water
reactions.conditions: violent; Na melts and skates on water surface; H2 may ignite with yellow flame
reactions.description: Alkali metal reacts violently with water. Na melts into a ball, dashes across surface. H2 may ignite.

reactions.name: Platinum dissolution in aqua regia
reactions.equation: 3 Pt(s) + 4 HNO3(aq) + 12 HCl(aq) -> 3 H2PtCl4(aq) + 4 NO(g) + 8 H2O(l)
reactions.conditions: aqua regia ('royal water') named for dissolving noble metals
reactions.description: Aqua regia dissolves platinum. Named 'royal water' by alchemists. Only method for dissolving Pt.

reactions.name: Rubidium in water
reactions.conditions: extremely violent; spontaneous ignition of H2; handled only in inert atmosphere
reactions.description: Extremely violent reaction. Ignites immediately on contact with water. Must handle under argon.

reactions.name: Tungsten highest melting point metal
reactions.conditions: 1073 K; hydrogen reduction of tungsten trioxide; used for light bulb filaments
reactions.description: Production of tungsten metal. Highest melting point of any element (3695K). Used in light bulb filaments.
